name: Böttcher–Wenzel conjecture
summary: The Böttcher–Wenzel conjecture is a mathematical statement that the square of the Frobenius norm of the commutator of two real matrices (\(||XY-YX||_{F}^{2}\)) is less than or equal to twice the product of their individual Frobenius norms squared (\(2||X||_{F}^{2}||Y||_{F}^{2}\)). This inequality, proposed by Böttcher and Wenzel in 2005, has been proven for general matrices and has applications in areas like quantum physics.
head: \(X\) and \(Y\) are any two real \(n\times n\) square matrices
